column1: ariannabotaku 161034842060 "2017-05-24 22:01:25 GMT" https://ariannabotaku.tumblr.com/post/161034842060/allistic-privileges-part-1 "sweetandsavageautistic: Allistic privilege is: -Being able to turn our stories into inspiration porn while us autistics try to say one word about how we see it and weâ€™re told to shut up.  -Writing articles about a person you know who is autistic and being seen as having a more valid case than if an actual autistic person made the very same case except using first person POV.  -Not having to worry about whether youâ€™re gonna be put under extended guardianship after you turn 18 or not and for how long and which rights you wonâ€™t have under it.  -Not having to worry about being told you donâ€™t know better about your sexuality because of your neurotype.  -Being able to apply for summer jobs or jobs in general without worrying that you revealing your neurotype could decrease your chances of getting said job.  -Not having to worry about
column2: if and when you get the job
column4: smaller pay) because of your neurotype. -Not having to be put in social skills classes and being taught the same lessons over and over again each year.  -Not having to worry about being talked down to because of your neurotype.  -Not having to worry about sharing your feelings
column6: because you feel like people expect your neurotype to be a smol
column8: sweet bean who never gets mad at anything and canâ€™t defend themselves (BTW
column9: if you see autistic people as what I just described
column10: get the fuck off of my page right now).  -Being able to headcanon characters to make them more relatable to you and not having to worry about people hating on you for it because of your neurotype.  -Not having to worry about making social mistakes because of your neurotype.  -Not having to worry about if the education system actually helps you or not.  -Not having your neurotype being used as a slur or insult on the internet.  -Not having your neurotype be seen the same as mental retardation.  -Not being told to keep your hands quiet when you move them to keep focus and calm yourself. -Not having to worry about if youâ€™ll be murdered because of your neurotype.  -If the above phrase happens
column11: your murderer wonâ€™t be let off because the murder was â€œan act of mercyâ€ due to your neurotype.  -Not needing certain accomodations because of your neurotype. And not having to worry about being denied said accomodations.  -Not having to worry about having a meltdown and having a family member film it and post it on the internet for everyone to see because of your neurotype.  -If youâ€™re trans
column12: not having to worry about being told that â€œyou donâ€™t know better about what gender you areâ€ because of your neurotype.  -Not having to worry about people talking about you behind your back because of your neurotype.  -Not having an entire organization advocate eugenics to get rid of people of your neurotype.  -Not having to worry about being told that your neurotype is caused by vaccines.  -Not having to worry about being institutionalized due to your neurotype.  -Your neurotype doesnâ€™t come with function labels
column13: which assume intelligence and competency.  -Not having to worry about being silenced because of your neurotype.  And if any allistics who find this get pissed at me for it because â€œItâ€™s no big deal. Get over itâ€ and â€œso-and-so isnâ€™t a privilegeâ€ and â€œallistic privilege doesnâ€™t exist
column14: â€ then youâ€™re only proving my point.  (AUTO POST)" False text

column1: ariannabotaku 161031994387 "2017-05-24 20:30:32 GMT" https://ariannabotaku.tumblr.com/post/161031994387/forget-the-myths-what-adhd-is-actually-like "neurodiversitysci: hobbitsaarebas:  phynali:  palpablenotion:  eglantinebr:  killergabite:  neurodiversitysci:                   This started life as a more accessible version of my ADHD list for writers
column2: and turned into a two-part series. Thatâ€™s how ADHD works sometimes. This is part 1. 1. Weâ€™re not all hyperactive
column3: extraverted little boys. We can be: Adults Female Not hyperactive (this is called Inattentive type).Â  Introverts Another myth is that men have hyperactive or combined ADHD and women have inattentive ADHD. But there are men with inattentive ADHD and women with hyperactive or combined ADHD. Theyâ€™re just less common. Yet another myth is that people with ADHD lose their hyperactive symptoms by the time they grow up. Many do
column4: but there are still adults with combined type around.  2. Some of us get good grades and behave well in school. A common myth about ADHD is that weâ€™re just misbehaving kids who need to be spanked more. Nonsense like this: But actually
column5: many of us looked more like this in school
column6: especially if we had Inattentive type ADHD. When bored
column9: or doodle. Teachers might not notice us
column10: or might even enjoy teaching us.   Furthermore
column11: some people with ADHD are smart
column13: and are interested in school. This lets them get good gradesâ€¦until the demands to turn organized work in on time become too overwhelming.  3. We can pay attention. We just canâ€™t regulateÂ our attention. Some parents and doctors claim a child canâ€™t have ADHD if they can focus on video games for hours. Nothing can be further from the truth. If anything
column14: we have trouble stopping! We can focus for hours on something that interests us. Or on procrastinating.  But weâ€™re worse than most people at focusing on things that are boring or unimportant to us.  We also have difficulty controlling the amount of attention we pay. Our attention works like this: When we pay full-on attention
column15: itâ€™s calledÂ â€œhyperfocus.â€ Hyperfocus is great when youâ€™re writing a paper
column16: but exhausting when youâ€™re doing mindless tasks like washing dishes or checking e-mail.  4. We donâ€™t always think fast
column18: or have lots of energy.                  Some of us struggle with fatigue and slow processing speed. In fact
column21: was proposed to describe this problem. The stereotype about ADHD is that we canâ€™t focus because there are too many thoughts and sensations in our heads
column22: and we keep jumping from one to another.  But those of us who fit the Sluggish Cognitive Tempo description can be distracted for very different reasons. Imagine how you feel after getting only three hours of sleep several nights in a row. You probably feel groggy
column23: have very few thoughts moving through your head
column24: and respond slowly when people talk to you. You probably have trouble concentrating
column27: and making decisions. Instead of having too many thoughts
column29: you have too few. You just feel like you donâ€™t have the energy to pay attention to anything. Thatâ€™s what itâ€™s like. This experience is sometimes calledÂ â€œbrain fog.â€ We can also have inconsistent processing speed.  Sometimes
column30: I think and talk so fast it irritates other people. Everything feels like itâ€™s happening in slow motion and I get bored. I interrupt other people because Iâ€™ve already processed what theyâ€™re saying before they finish
column31: and I donâ€™t realize itâ€™s my listening thatâ€™s finished
column33: I am just about to answer someoneâ€™s question when they irritably repeat themselves
column34: or ask why Iâ€™m taking so long to answer. It feels like Iâ€™m thinking at normal speed
column35: but other peopleâ€™s reactions make clear that Iâ€™m going too slow.   5. Weâ€™re not all athletic adrenaline junkies. Thereâ€™s a stereotype that weâ€™re adrenaline junkies who perform surgeries
column37: or travel round the world starting new businesses.    First of all
column38: many of us have delays or disabilities with motor coordination. As children
column39: people with ADHD can have difficulty with: Using scissors Handwriting Tying shoes Throwing or catching a ball Riding a bike Second
column40: when you look at the people with ADHD who fit this stereotype
column41: what do they have in common? Most are men
column42: with high energy and either hyperactive/impulsive or combined type ADHD. Even in mice
column43: male and female brains react to stress differently. Itâ€™s possible that men
column45: are more likely to thrive on stress. By contrast
column47: and might get overwhelmed instead. Up to a certain point
column48: increasing stress helps you focus. Thatâ€™s why some people wait until the last minute to study for exams. But past a certain amount
column49: becoming more stressed starts to hurt you. And long term
column50: living under high stress hurts both your physical and mental health. Some people with ADHD rely on increasing their stress levels to get stuff done. A disability services counselor I met in graduate school actually recommended this strategy to me.Â  She should have known better. Even if you benefit from putting yourself under stress
column51: you will pay steep long-term costs. Having seen family and friends pay them
column52: I donâ€™t think the costs are worth it.  TL;DR
column53: Not all of us benefit from stress
column54: so we donâ€™t all seek it out.  6. Some of us are socially awkward penguins
column55: not social butterflies. Another stereotype describes us as social butterflies who hide our school difficulties by playing class clown or making friends with everyone. But some of us are socially awkward. We can come off as awkward or rude because weâ€™re not paying attention and miss cues. We can have poor sense of timing and inconsistent processing speed. These can make us interrupt other people
column56: or just seem weird. We can be annoying. We interrupt other people
column59: or zone out in the middle of a conversation. Like elderly people
column60: we can tell you the same thing many times because we forgot we told you. We also often forget what you tell us. It takes heroic effort to remember
column63: many of us have mild social difficulties that donâ€™t meet criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder.   People with ADHD are also more likely to be on the autism spectrum.Â   7. Being diagnosed and labeled can improve our lives. People worry about letting their child be diagnosed or labeled
column64: because they think it will make people treat their child worse. But when you actually talk to people with ADHD
column65: many of them had a very different experience. Having the label is a relief. It gives you understanding. It gives you words to describe your experiences for the first time. It means youâ€™re not broken. It means there are other people like you. The title of a popular ADHD book
column68: or crazy?â€ describes the feeling well.                  Iâ€™ve written about how bad it is to grow up without a diagnosis
column69: and how good it feels to get one
column72: and here.  8. Stimulants donâ€™t turn you into a zombie
column74: either. If a person with ADHD gets the right medication at the right dose
column75: they donâ€™t turn into zombies. They just become a better-functioning version of themselves. But stimulants donâ€™t cure ADHD. Yes
column76: if taken for a long time
column77: they do create changes in the brain. But the person still has the same underlying characteristics. If they stop taking stimulants
column78: their ADHD symptoms will become visible again. Stimulants
column80: should be thought of like insulin for diabetics. Theyâ€™re not a cure
column81: and they need to be taken long-term. But they help you manage your symptoms and live a full life.  9. Stimulants arenâ€™t the only way to manage ADHD
column82: and some of us choose not to take them. Some people with ADHD choose not to take stimulants. And itâ€™s not just because they hate drug companies or fear that the drugs will turn them into a different person. First of all
column83: only 80% of people with ADHD respond to stimulants. The other fifth can try other kinds of medications. These include: wakefulness medications (like Provigil)
column84: medications that treat mood disorders (like Welbutrin)
column86: Concerta)Non-stimulants are less powerful than stimulants
column87: so they reduce ADHD symptoms less
column88: but they also have fewer side effects. Which brings me to the main reason people with ADHD avoid stimulants: side effects. Stimulants activate the sympathetic nervous systemâ€”the one involved in the fight or flight response. As a result
column89: you can get the following side effects: Increased heart rateIncreased anxietyLoss of appetiteIncreased rate of headaches and migrainesWeight lossNote: These symptoms are probably the reason for the claim that stimulants stunt childrenâ€™s growth. If weâ€™re not taking stimulants
column90: you might see us consuming huge quantities of more socially acceptable drugs: caffeine and nicotine. That person who goes through a pot of coffee a day
column91: always has a Pepsi in hand
column92: or canâ€™t quit smoking?  They might be self-medicating their ADHD.  Please share this information and help combat myths about ADHD.  This sounds very familiar  Best explanation I have ever seen. Describes me and my whole family.   Can someone explain the caffeine self medicating topic?  Caffeine is a stimulant and can be used in place of other medical stimulants. Even people without ADHD can use it to help them focus
column93: but some people drink a lot more than they might otherwise â€œneedâ€ because they rely on it to help them focus or modulate their attention. I try to keep an eye on my caffeine intake but definitely use it to self-medicate and drink more than many people my size.  Another friend of mine with undiagnosed ADHD can go through pots of the stuff.  Much as I appreciate the information in this post
column94: I donâ€™t appreciate its binarism and cissexism
column95: especially in phrasing likeÂ â€œmale and female brains.â€ There is no such thing as a male brain or a female brain. Different individuals express their ADHD differently
column97: some of those differences occur along gender lines
column98: I think that can be attributed to social training/privilege and hormone levels. Hormones and social training/privilege both have a profound impact on our emotions
column101: and account for the observable differences between cis men and women.Â   First of all
column103: thanks for the helpful feedback. It sounds like the post came across in ways I didnâ€™t intend and didnâ€™t think about clarifying while writing. (TBH
column104: my main concern was keeping everything concise
column105: given my ADHD audience). I hope this reply will address your concerns
column106: even though Iâ€™m not 100% clear on where youâ€™re talking about sex and where youâ€™re talking about gender. You might have noticed that the post talks separately about sex and gender. I discuss sex only in regards to response to anxiety
column107: and gender in terms of social influences like who gets diagnosed
column108: how other people interpret their behavior
column110: the points about sex arenâ€™t intended to apply only to cis people. Because this is a point about biology
column114: a â€œfemaleâ€ pattern whether they are a man
column118: etc. I probably should have said that explicitly. (I also understand that the effects of gender will change if/when a person changes gender identities
column119: and might apply in more complicated ways to trans people. I also donâ€™t have the research knowledge or life experience to talk about that. If you do
column120: Iâ€™d like to hear about it).Â  Youâ€™re absolutely right
column121: mice and humans are very different because as far as we know
column122: mice just have biological sex variables like hormones and neural growth patterns in response to stress. But humans layer other things on top
column124: and different socialization for males and females. Youâ€™re right
column125: I should have said this explicitly. It feels like a truism to me
column127: no one knows whatâ€™s obvious to you. ;) Â  I also want to add
column128: biological sex differences in the brain are often overstated
column129: and are used to explain human behaviors that go way beyond any sort of brain-behavior mechanism we know about
column130: and could be explained way more parsimoniously by culture. You were saying thereâ€™s no such thing as a man or female brain. I would say that â€œmaleâ€ and â€œfemaleâ€ brains exist
column131: only in the sense that there are differences in hormones and neural growth patterns between the brains that come with a male body versus a female body. Not in the sense that people like Simon Baron-Cohen or many evolutionary psychologists talk about it. The mouse research is the only specific difference I know of that seems both real and relevant to humans
column132: and there are lots of other influences on how men and women deal with stress
column133: too.Â  I think (and probably discuss in the post?) that gender can be a powerful social force with huge effects on who gets diagnosed when
column135: and how they learn to cope or compensate. Anecdotally
column136: I see and hear about such gender differences often.Â  I do have a bias from personal experience
column138: in thinking about gender as concepts that are imposed from the outside (which of course can fit more or less well
column139: and a person can adopt to any extent for themselves or not at all). If there are other more internal ways that gender works
column140: I canâ€™t imagine them at the moment. But Iâ€™d be happy to learn more. The reason for this blind spot is probably also the reason that I didnâ€™t think to be clear about sex and gender in the original post. MyÂ gender is about as essential to my identity as my eye color: itâ€™s a concept that other people find useful
column141: that hurts me only when combined with sexism
column142: and that I think about only when other people make it an issue (for better or worse). (There are surely both biological and cultural reasons for this ;D). Being trans doesnâ€™t seem worse or less natural to me than being cis
column143: but neither really make intuitive sense to meâ€“nor does any way of identifying strongly with any gender. So
column145: itâ€™s possible that Iâ€™ve missed less-obvious ways that gender can interact with ADHD. If so
column146: it would be helpful to hear about it!Â  Thanks again for taking the time to share your thoughts
column147: in such a clear and respectful way!  (AUTO POST)" False text

ariannabotaku 160969786343 "2017-05-23 02:30:58 GMT" https://ariannabotaku.tumblr.com/post/160969786343/solar-system-things-to-know-this-week "nasa: Jupiter
column2: our solar systemâ€™s largest planet
column3: is making a good showing in night skies this month. Look for it in the southeast in each evening. With binoculars
column4: you may be able to see the planetâ€™s four largest moons. Here are some need-to-know facts about the Here are some need-to-know facts about the King of the Planets. 1.Â The Biggest Planet:  With a radius of 43
column7: Jupiter is 11 times wider than Earth. If Earth were the size of a nickel
column8: Jupiter would be about as big as a basketball. 2.Â Fifth in Line Jupiter orbits our sun
column9: and is the fifth planet from the sun at a distance of about 484 million miles (778 million km) or 5.2 Astronomical Units (AU). Earth is one AU from the sun. 3.Â Short Day / Long Year  One day on Jupiter takes about 10 hours (the time it takes for Jupiter to rotate or spin once). Jupiter makes a complete orbit around the sun (a year in Jovian time) in about 12 Earth years (4
column10: 333 Earth days). 4.Â Whatâ€™s Inside?  Jupiter is a gas-giant planet without a solid surface. However
column11: the planet may have a solid
column12: inner core about the size of Earth. 5.Â Atmosphere  Jupiterâ€™s atmosphere is made up mostly of hydrogen (H2) and helium (He). 6.Â Many Moons  Jupiter has 53 known moons
column13: with an additional 14 moons awaiting confirmation of their discovery â€” a total of 67 moons. 7.Â Ringed World  All four giant planets in our solar system have ring systems and Jupiter is no exception. Its faint ring system was discovered in 1979 by the Voyager 1 mission.Â  8.Â Exploring Jupiter:  Many missions have visited Jupiter and its system of moons. The Juno spacecraft is currently orbiting Jupiter. 9.Â Ingredients for Life?  Jupiter cannot support life as we know it. However
column14: some of Jupiterâ€™s moons have oceans underneath their crusts that might support life. 10.Â Did You Know?  Jupiterâ€™s Great Red Spot is a gigantic storm (about the size of Earth) that has been raging for hundreds of years. Discover more lists of 10 things to know about our solar system HERE. Make sure to follow us on Tumblr for your regular dose of space: http://nasa.tumblr.com  (AUTO POST)" False text

column1: ariannabotaku 160821613496 "2017-05-19 01:01:04 GMT" https://ariannabotaku.tumblr.com/post/160821613496/strangerdarkerbetter-shoutout-to-all-the-weird "strangerdarkerbetter: Shoutout to all the weird kidsTo the kids that everyone called weird or strange or worseTo the kids who were/are being bullied by their peersTo the autistic and ADHD kids who are mocked for their stimsÂ To the autistic kids who are bullied for not understanding sarcasm/being gullibleTo the ADHD kids who are punished for not being able to sit stillTo the autistic kids who are mocked for their meltdownsÂ To the kids who are segregated from theÂ â€œnormalâ€ kidsTo the adults who are still recovering from the abuse they faced at the hands of their peersTo the adults who still feel like weirdos and freaks and still hear their voices echoing in our headsTo the adults who donâ€™t remember their childhoods because of all the abuse we faced for daring to be differentYouâ€™re not weird or strange or bad. You are different and that is beautiful. I know it may not seem that way right now. I know how much it hurts to be singled out and abused for your natural way of being. I know how hard you try to hide your differences to avoid the torment. I know how much you suffer for suppressing your natural behaviors.Â But
column2: your differences are something to be admired and embraced. You are so beautiful and unique. Your stims are a marvelous and something to be celebrated. Your way of seeing the world may not fit with how others see things but that is part of what makes you so special.Â One day
column3: you will find people who expect you as you are. One day
column4: you will find people who donâ€™t just tolerate you but celebrate all the things that make youÂ â€œweirdâ€. One day
column5: you will find peace with yourself and be able to accept yourself. One day
column6: you will walk the road of recovery
column7: leaving behind all the painful taunts
column8: all the bullying and abuse. One day
column9: you will find healing and hope.Â " False text

column1: ariannabotaku 160708538736 "2017-05-15 21:46:32 GMT" https://ariannabotaku.tumblr.com/post/160708538736/good-samaritan "A post I did for Facebook:I know some acquaintances of mine that are for Trumpcare. Â I believe that if you are going to make me pay extra fees because of something I have no control over I should be able to sue those that caused my problem. Â I have seen the issue with preexisting conditions and lifetime caps and how they will affect me. Â I can hear you now â€œWait
column2: what
column4: sue why?â€ Â First let me say this
column5: most of my preexisting conditions I had ABSOLUTELY NO CONTROL over how they came about. Â Yes I am overweight and my cholesterol is a little off
column6: but I am not talking about that here. Â In this article I am strictly talking about my major depression.Now yes
column7: I was genetically predisposed to major depression
column8: but a predisposition is not the same as having it. Â How did one of my major mental illnesses come about
column11: because of adults at school and church
column13: because of certain family members and finally the WONDERFUL religion of Christianity played a roll but the last part is for later. Â The majority is because I was the bottom of the bottom. Â I was bullied at school
column14: both mentally and physically (imagine getting picked up by your neck and choked weekly 10 feet away from a teacher who does nothing). Â I was told over and over again by teachers and counselors it was all my fault. Â I was bullied in public to the point police were called multiple times and never did anything. Â Even in the â€œholyâ€ place of church I was not only bullied by the kids but made fun of even by the â€œupstandingâ€ adult members of the church. Â I could go on
column15: but instead I will give you a guess as to where the majority of my major depression comes from. Â Now I will admit my autism has caused some issues (confusion due to literal thinking
column16: not understanding social cues and nonverbal communications
column19: etcâ€¦).For those of you that want Trumpcare and had anything to do with the previous paragraph
column20: if I have to pay extra fees for what some of you did or allowed to happen I should be able to SUE you for the money to pay the extra fees. Â Yes
column21: I should be able to SUE you as YOUR PARTY thinks that this is my fault and according to YOUR PARTY I should be liable for extra fees. Â Now I know what you are thinking
column23: you have a job and wonâ€™t have problems. Â First
column24: let me say I will have a problem with lifetime caps
column25: 100%! Â Last year my mental health bill was $55
column27: guess what the LIFETIME mental health cap by BCBS of Nebraska was before ACA? Â It was $50
column28: 000 IN A LIFETIME! Â So yes
column29: I WOULD have a HUGE problem. Â As far as preexisiting conditions go SWITCH A JOB! Â  Before the ACA when you switched a job there was a period where they would not cover preexisting conditions. Â I know
column30: many of you have forgotten that! Â Also
column31: try and afford COBRA if you have been laid off
column32: YAH RIGHT. Â COBRA is the biggest lie! Â When I got laid off from Inventive Communications the COBRA insurance was about 75% of the amount I was getting for unemployment while looking for a job. Â I could not afford that and eat
column34: or use any form of transportation to even find a job
column35: so I HAD to go without and donâ€™t give me your BULLSHIT about I had a choice
column36: the only choice is your choice to hate others. Â I had to go to free clinics for health care
column37: clinics where I was treated like the worst in society. Â Any of you that went through CMHC know what I mean. Â Clinics where the staff would yell at you and call you names. Â Clinics that were little more than revolving doors. Â I hate to see what it would be like now
column38: now that I came out as Transgender and most free services are religious based and in the current climate of hatred this means like most I would either have to detransition or go without. Â But in the end most likely the only way I would get medications is Planned Parenthood for my HRT (thank G-d they are around) and the ER or Crisis Center for my mental health.I do not write this for your sympathy

Â We need a system where people no longer fall through the cracks. Â We need a system not run by money grubbing companies that only care about profits. Â It is fine if you want to buy extra insurance

column44: and yes having health insurance means you have a PRIVILEGE. Â I know

column73: you are probirth. Â And no

ariannabotaku 161063505326 "2017-05-25 17:40:34 GMT" https://ariannabotaku.tumblr.com/post/161063505326/asan-statement-on-presidential-budget "autisticadvocacy:  ASAN strongly condemns the deep cuts  that the Presidentâ€™s proposed budget would make to Medicaid
column2: Social  Security
column3: and other critical programs for people with disabilities. The  Presidentâ€™s proposal would deprive countless Americans with disabilities  of critical health care and community-based supports. It would jeopardize our very lives and result in a massive return to nursing homes and institutions.  ASAN calls on Congress to reject these devastating cuts and craft a  budget that invests in people with disabilities
column5: and our  communities. We have come too far to go back. The Presidentâ€™s budget would require  massive cuts to Medicaid
column6: which acts as a lifeline for countless people  with disabilities. Medicaid is not only a critical source of health care  coverage but also the main funder for home and community-based services  and supports that help us live in the community instead of  institutions. But the Presidentâ€™s budget takes the $800 billion in  Medicare cuts proposed by the American Health Care Act and adds an extra $610 billion in additional cuts. This will reduce Medicaid funding by more than a trillion dollars over the next 10 years â€“ a change that would cut the program in half. Â  This budget would eliminate $47 million for research on health care and services for autistic people and our families  that was provided via the Autism CARES Act. These services include the  Leadership Education in Neurodevelopmental and Other Related  Disabilities (LEND) and Developmental Behavioral Pediatrics (DBP)  programs which train healthcare professionals to work with autistic  people. These cuts are in addition to $5.8 billion in cuts to the  National Institutes of Health and $35 million in cuts to CDC work  related to autism and developmental disability. The budget would also cut Social Security at the same time that it cuts programs that help us find jobs in the community. It promises $50 billion in cuts to Social Security Disability.  The only way to achieve such stark cuts is to kick people with  disabilities off the program
column7: through punitive and impossible-to-meet  work requirements or other harsh changes which will result in people  losing their Social Security. While ASAN has always supported programs  to help people with disabilities find employment
column8: these cuts arenâ€™t  designed to move people to quality jobs that help them escape poverty.  In fact
column9: the budget would also cut all Vocational Rehabilitation funding for state supported employment grants
column10: which are instrumental in helping people with intellectual and  developmental disabilities get and keep real jobs in the community. Furthermore
column11: it would punish SSI recipients for living together  â€“ including couples and families â€“ by reducing their SSI payments. SSI  programs already force people with disabilities to survive on an average  of just $18 per day. Further cuts would force SSI recipients to choose between separation and starvation. To  make it worse
column12: the Presidentâ€™s budget would also make massive cuts to  programs that are critical to people with disabilities living in  poverty
column13: including a $193 billion cut to the Supplemental Nutritional Assistance Program (SNAP)
column15: over the next ten years; completely eliminating the Low Income Home Energy Assistance Program (LIHEAP) that helps low-income people pay their heating bills; and a $72 million cut to substance abuse prevention programs. In addition to cuts to our health care and community-based services
column16: our community would see a $25 million cut to programs to build affordable community-based housing for people with disabilities  and a $7.7 billion cut to affordable housing programs overall. These  cuts could cause over 250
column17: 000 people to lose the housing vouchers. The  budget would eliminate the National Housing Trust Fund
column18: which helps people with extremely low incomes escape or avoid homelessness. For  thousands of people with disabilities who are already struggling to  make ends meet
column19: these cuts will mean homelessness or imprisonment in an  institution. Finally
column20: this budget would cut  smaller but vital programs that increase inclusion and independence for  people with disabilities and our families. This budget would cut all federal funding for the Special Olympics
column21: would eliminate programs that provide free legal assistance to people with low incomes
column22: and would sharply reduce funding for State Councils on Developmental  Disabilities
column26: and the Substance Abuse and Mental Health  Services Administration. Â People with disabilitiesâ€™ lives have value and  are worth investing in. We deserve more than this. When Congress threatened to cut Medicaid by over $800 billion
column27: we showed up to fight.  Congress heard from the disability community in town halls
column30: and letters. That fight isnâ€™t overâ€“but we  can win
column31: and we can beat these cuts too.  We call on Congress to reject the Presidentâ€™s attack on the supports we  need to live in the community. Our lives are too important to be put on  the chopping block. " False link
